story.text: (Updates figures, adds details, comments)TORONTO Jan 3 (Reuters) - The Toronto Stock Exchange's main index fell shortly after market open on Wednesday as weaker resource and energy issues dragged the broader benchmark into the red. The S&P/TSX composite index was down 48.52 points, or 0.4 percent, at 12,875.14 shortly after the year's second session kicked off, reversing the 15-point gain made on Tuesday. "Obviously, it is a reflection of the 45 percent of the index that's in oil and materials," said Gavin Graham, chief investment officer at the Guardian Group of Funds in Toronto. Eight of the composite's 10 main groups advanced. But the heavyweight materials sector, which includes gold miners, and the energy sector lost 1.42 percent and 1.75 percent, respectively. The key groups' declines reflected softness in their underlying commodity prices. Oil fell below $60 a barrel as warm weather in the United States ate into heating oil demand. Base metals also fell, dragged down by copper prices which touched their lowest levels since early April. Oil and base metals are "the two areas where you have liquid, traded contracts that can be easily speculated in," Graham said. Speculation can add to market volatility. Zinc giant Teck Cominco Ltd. (TCKb.TO) was among the biggest losers, dropping C$2.95, or 3.4 percent, to C$82.98. Energy giant EnCana Corp. (ECA.TO) eased 90 Canadian cents to C$53.45. Inmet Mining IMN.TO dove C$4.29, or 7 percent, to C$56.49. Trading volumes are only beginning to return to normal levels following the Christmas and New Year holiday break. As well, U.S. traders are back at their desks for the first time this week following a day of mourning for former U.S. President Gerald Ford which kept stock exchanges south of the border closed on Tuesday. ($1=$1.17 Canadian)
story.title: softer resources , energy drag down toronto stocks
